div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin May 13th 1916
div1.p: Well, the easy life is over now and we’re off for the work ahead. Its up at 3 A.M. and to bed after dinner. My machine seems to be good and climbs well, and now to master it as best I can. I’ve been running around the country, but now that my mitrailleuse is ready I’m doing the real work.

This morning Chapman and I were the Luxeuil guard but if the people were aware of my utter unfamiliarity with
the job they wouldn’t have slept so soundly. At 6.30 the Captain ordered a “sortie en escadrille” over the lines. It was not good weather, the sky having various layers of clouds, and so it was hard to find one’s way. It struck me as amusing in a way to be going out. But few of us knew anything about what should be done, and for the first time I tried to cock a mitrailleuse — but there we were — just as if we knew something about it. The first thing I did was to lose the rest.
I had been climbing fast and was up in the clouds. The ground below was so hazy I did not make it out and I felt lost. I was at 3000 meters then and floating in an unknown sea. It was like a sea, the ice covered sea we entered when we left St. Pierre - Miquelon so long ago. To the south the Alps jutted up glistening like ice bergs. Suddenly I saw a little black speck just above the clouds to my left and recognized it as one of the “Babies”. Two, then three, popped up into
view. I went over towards them. The clouds had now begun to disperse and I could see the ground well below me and picked out a canal I located on my map that led to the Rhine. Then we veered to the north east and I saw the trenches. Suddenly a series of white puffs appeared to my right and below me and I realized we were being fired at. It was more amusing than alarming for they were not coming close.
They did, however, seem to be near a machine I saw below me. I was at 4,200 m. then, and higher than the rest. Finally the little puffs began to come nearer. Some were green, others white and the big ones black. One went off at my altitude to the left — the next one nearer and I figured the third would be about right, but it wasn’t and after that they were away off. Yesterday they shot better. Rockwell, Chapman and Thaw
got it heavy. Thaw’s propellor [sic] was nicked by an eclat and the landing bumper on his tail shot away. We fooled around over Germany for about fifteen minutes. I became interested in looking at the Rhine and then had trouble finding any of our seven planes. I hadn’t the remotest idea how far north or south I was. We couldn’t find a single Boche plane tho [sic] we had sneaked in back of where they ought to have been working over
the lines. In a short while I will feel ashamed of having written about all these details — the shooting etc., for it will be an old story, and I’ll feel like a kid who has found interest in nothing, for having told it.

To morrow the army moving picture outfit is to take us for the French propoganda [sic] in America. We’ve staged a big show in connection with the bombardment machines here. It will be very funny to go thru [sic] with
it.
I love your concern about Chapman. Would he lack personality, because, before, he had sent no message?
Betty Baldwin is quite her self again as far as mind is concerned, so her mother writes me, but she is not allowed as yet to know of the torpedoing of the ship. Funny, that.
